Nikolai, I think your question is essentially about vocabulary.  You are as=
king whether the substrate would still be called an ANN if it contained non=
-sigmoidal nodes.  I believe no one has evolved such substrates (i.e. with =
different activation functions), so I think it is a theoretical question, b=
ut I think what you are saying is probably correct.  The substrate does not=
 need to be an ANN.  Of course, some ANNs do not use sigmoids (such as RBF =
networks), so just because the nodes are not sigmoids does not guarantee th=
at it is not an ANN, but in some cases I would agree it is not an ANN.  

I=
 would be careful with the term "tree" because most graphs are not "trees,"=
 so I would not call it an "expression tree" unless it really was somehow f=
orced to produce trees or somehow output a tree as the optimal result.  Whe=
ther it would be called "simple" is also probably a matter of opinion.  Gen=
erally, if there are many connections it may not really be simple, but it m=
ay be simple if the connection weights of those connections adhere to a sim=
ple underlying pattern.

I hope this answer helps clarify some of your ques=
tions.

ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Nikolai" <ker_31_toluca@...> w=
rote:
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:=

> >
> > Nikolai, you have the main idea right but the one aspect of your 
=
> > description that I would correct is the idea that the substrate must
> =
> be a perceptron.
> 
> thanks Ken, as I understood, you call 'substrate' a=
 final ANN that evaluates the solution to the problem activating each node =
one by one where each node uses the same activation function.
> In a paper =
about CPPNs you say that CPPN is not an ANN and this is why it is called 'C=
PPN', i agree. But when a CPPN produces weights for an ANN, the result (sub=
strate) must be an ANN. If each node of the substrate is not perceptron typ=
e (i.e does not have a sigmoid activation function), then we can not call i=
t an ANN, right ? It could be called as some sort of an "expression tree"? =
And if it does not have many hidden layers, it would represent a simple (re=
petitive, symmetrical, etc) expression. A 'simple expression at large scale=
' if it is dealing with large number of connections. 
> Please correct me i=
f i am missing something.
> Thanks
> Nikolai
>
